This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 you're doing a great job. Thanks jurist. You're amazing. Why hello everybody. It's so uh it's
so awesome to be here today. I'm excited to bring you uh one of my passion projects called
Private Keys in Public Places. Before we get started I'll let you know who I am. My name is
Tom Pohl. Um I'm the penetration testing team manager for LMG security out of Missoula
Montana. Uh I like to do things like play CTFs. Uh I I I'm a I you know a pen penetration
tester by day, dream crusher at night. Um I've won a few CTFs. Uh I've won black badge here
at DEF CON. I've uh won like gold badge at DOT CON and couple at Wild West Hackin' Fest.
Three times at Circle City Camp. But uh I am an evil twin. I'd like to point out uh hi Andy.
My twin brother is uh this is his first DEF CON. He is here in the audience tonight. So if you
see me around the con and I look like I don't know what I'm doing, it's probably him.
Ha ha ha. At any rate um and this is me hard at work. My wife took a picture that just doesn't
exist uh of me uh in a hacker hoodie. I don't think I've ever worn a hoodie besides this
picture in my life. Uh at any rate I want to give a shout out. Uh greets to uh Sec KC and Sec
DSM as Juris said. You know in Des Moines we like to call ourselves uh Sec KC's little
brother cause we kick the we kick him in the shins. The last time I saw Juris I was uh
giving a talk at Sec KC and we had just deprived him of being able to mine cryptocurrency of
the Sec KC coin. And uh they used it to buy swag and and I gave him a paper wallet with 500
Sec KC coin in it so he could buy himself a little patch of swag at the Sec KC store. And
then I gave paper wallets to everybody in the room because they were taped under their
seats. It was great. Anyways. Love those guys. Greets to to Sec KC. And I want to give a
special thanks to my buddy Nick Stark, my partner in crime, thought crimes. Uh and he's
really the reason why I started looking for private keys. Uh we'll get into that in a little
bit. And also Sherry Davidoff. She couldn't be here today. My wife. Uh she's amazing. This
talk would not have existed without her because she's been urging me to create this for
years. Literally years cause I've been been at this for quite some time. Thank you so much
my love. I hope you're watching. Uh so the roadmap. So we're gonna talk a little bit of
background uh and then we're gonna get into three different uh examples of how I find
private keys in public places. And then we'll get at the very end into some recommendations.
So first of all why do we care about private keys? Right? It's not you know the hot sexy
new uh vulnerability out there. In fact there's some really great projects out there that
are uh extracting private keys and and doing things. But I don't I don't think it gets as
much air time and publicity as as it as it needs because this is a systemic problem. And
it's happening in the real world. Right? As attackers uh get into your networks uh they're
looking for easy ways to gain more and more access. And this is in using keys especially in
the in cloud environments is definitely uh a a a way that people are do that the the bad
guys are doing it. Right? So we really need to raise awareness for this. So once upon a
time uh back in January 2020 imagine this is pre-COVID. Right? Nobody knew what COVID was
back then. I was at a a conference and my buddy Nick Stark he's over there in the audience. Hi
Nick. I love you. Uh he was he he texted I think he texted me. I think you were we were texting.
We weren't talking that day. And he was angry at Netgear cause he found a bunch of
vulnerabilities. He's if you don't know Nick Stark look him up. He's like the hacker's
hacker. Like he is amazing. And uh he found a bunch of problems on Netgear and they're
trying to like bundle them all into one even though like it's totally different problems. Uh
and so he called me being angry about it. And I'm like trying to console him. I'm like you
know what? Here's how we're gonna do we're let's just go hack some shit. And I'm like you
know I'm like no idea. I'm like he's like what should we hack on? Hint hint. Netgear. Since
he was angry at Netgear like let's just go start pulling random firmware and let's start
exploring it and see if we can find anything. And uh we were about 3 firmwares in probably
before um uh looking and we found 2 different certificates that were publicly uh uh CA blast
certificates with their associated private keys. Both for routerlogin.net and the
mini app uh funjsq.com. Both from from reputable uh certificate authorities. Like the
certificate's there, it's not expired, and the private key's with it. Um and just to show
you uh I actually took those keys, put them on my own server, I you know controlled the DNS
for an environment, went to it, sure enough you get you know a happy lock icon, the
certificate's a valid, the whole deal. Because I controlled the cert the uh the DNS. And
it's like ok well you a lot of people are like whoa that's not a big deal is it? Uh and and
actually it is. There's a couple guys that went out there and and wrote some really good
articles about like actually this is a pretty big deal. You know and uh I am uh a
professional bad guy. Or a good guy. I'm helping you I'm out there helping people find
vulnerabilities on their network right? But I was kinda you know thinking about like if I
was to be a bad guy uh eh what what would I do right? Like say I was targeting an
individual and I went to the same coffee shop they were in right? I could set up you know my
fake routerlogin.net and if I knew they were running this Netgear product uh you know I
could uh fake the DNS, force their computer to come to my fake website and then if they
save their password when they log into their router I can get that password right? I can have
them autofill that password and then do a auto submit and then I'll get their password and
then uh uh if uh um uh if they have remote administration at home then I could go log into
their home router and play with them all day long. Or you know if they have the same
password say we're gonna do a credential stuffing attack I could go then maybe log into
some of their other services across the internet. Alright by the way I wanted to say if
anybody's got questions while I'm talking through this feel free to jump up I think there's a
mic in the middle in the back and interrupt me cause I love interaction. In fact I brought
with me some Montana hacker shot glasses so if you got a good question I will chuck these at
you for a good question. So there's a bounty on good questions here. Um alright so we tried
to tell Netgear right? Uh it was what January 14th so really early in January was when we
found it and we went you know we tried to contact Netgear actually in a couple different
ways. The most we had gotten was through their direct message on Twitter or X or whatever
it's called now. Um and then uh so we decided that was like kind of a no go they weren't
really wanting to talk to us so we reached out to Bug Crowd who ran their bug bounty
program to try to establish communications. And uh they came back and they would not
accept information about our vulnerability outside of their program. Which was really
frustrating because uh here's why. Uh they require what's called responsible disclosure.
So anybody that's familiar with bug bounty programs there's a couple different ways you you
can uh disclose right? There's responsible disclosure and then there's coordinated
disclosure. Right? They didn't uh they're uh in in I've got people that are very familiar
with this where basically you go to the bug bounty program, you report the vulnerability,
they pay you the money and then they never fix it. And guess what? You can't ever talk about
it, you can't force the issue, you're bound by their terms and they never have to do
anything about it. Basically you report it and you have to walk away. Uh and uh so we we
didn't want to go that route. We wanted to do coordinated disclosure where we're basically
like hey we're going to talk about this, we want to set up a timeline, we want to talk with
you and and make sure it works with you. And they weren't having it. Uh so we went ahead
and uh publicly disclosed within a few days and they fixed it within like a week. Uh and
actually April of uh 2020 even Bruce Schneier came out and said that bug bounty programs
were being used to buy silence. So you know uh sorry if if uh this impacted you but you
know I think this is an important issue. I think more and more uh programs should do
coordinated disclosure instead of responsible disclosure just so that we're forcing these
vendors to fix their products. Alright. So what did we learn from Netgear? Uh number one uh
private keys can be trivially found. Uh I literally we just did grep on the file you know we
we extracted the file system into folders and we like recursively grepped for the word
private in all caps and out came some keys. So we started to wonder you know was this a
fluke? Was this just like this is the one product out there that's got private keys in it?
Uh and the answer oddly enough is no. This is this is not a this is not an isolated incident.
Uh so we started to ask uh what else might have private keys? So let's take a look. At the
time I was working for a software as a for service company as I'd actually been spent most
of my career on the blue team side uh building software as a service uh platform and uh I
was a Fortinet customer and I'm like you know what let me go download the latest version of the
software that runs all of my firewalls just to take a look to see what I can find. Guess what I
found? Well first of all uh uh I was able to download the uh the the software and it was a
VMDK right right off their website and I extracted the file system and I found that most of
the stuff were there's uh most of the software is in these tar.xz files on the uh on the on the
firmware and I'm like okay cool so it's an xz exact you know nor normally people don't use
xz uh compression but that's cool I'll go with it uh and uh even if you ran file on it says
they're xz compressed data uh so look what happens when we go ahead and try to decompress it
right? Oh xz sorry compressed data is corrupt. Like that's interesting. Uh so uh it's I mean
it's brand new firmware I just downloaded from their website extracted I extracted it through
very solid techniques I knew this stuff wasn't corrupted and actually I intentionally uh
downloaded the x86 64 bit version of the software because uh uh I I knew I wouldn't have any
you know weird file system issues and and and things of that nature. Uh and so when I started
exploring this file system more I saw that they had a couple utilities outside of those xz
files and a bunch of libraries. They had one called ftar and they had another utility called
xz. I'm like this is interesting. You couldn't just run uh the uh the xz binaries or the ftar
binaries because they had their own libraries associated with it. But uh if I ran a chroot uh
if I ran their their uh firmware in a chroot environment mind you I had my virtual machine
I'm running this on is the same architecture as the version I downloaded that's really
important if you're gonna do this at home. Uh and so I ran their xz binaries and their ftar
binaries guess what happened? I was able to decompress and extract the rest of the file
system into files. For a shy class why do you think they did that? Anybody? Security by
security. Rick's in. Yes. Alright that's exactly right. Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha. Alright
so uh so you know now that we've extracted all these files out in the file system we're like
there's gotta be something good here cause they've hidden it. They've made it a little bit
hard. So I play a lot of CTFs so far we're at like maybe a level level 100 challenge right?
This stuff is not hard. So if if I wanna I wanna encourage everyone that if you do uh uh CTFs
and you know hacking in the real world is generally easier uh than than some of these CTF
challenges. Uh and I'm not I'm not joking. Uh I'm not doing anything that that is really
hard or complex but I think it's overlooked. I think there's there's uh there's things
that that people don't realize that if you even you know remotely try to go look at you're
gonna find some some pretty terrifying things. Alright so we're gonna use the same
technique before. Strings on a find maybe. Little bit of grep dash r. Yeah and guess what
we find? Two publicly blessed CA or certificates blessed by CAs. These this time one was
published by Apple. The other one from Google. Any idea what these were used for? Push

Oh overshot. My uh NFL career is uh is not gonna take off. Uh yes we found some push
notification certificates in everyone's Fortinet firewall. Is that exciting or scary? It's pretty
excitingly scary. Yeah I know. Uh so just to show you so uh I'm like really? These are really
Apple certificates? And sure enough so here's the the output right here uh from uh looking at
the the PEM certificate the the public cert uh part of the key or part of public part of the
certificate and it's uh the CN from Apple Worldwide Developer Relations Certificate uh
Relations Certificate uh right there. Apple and uh and then so you can you know
cryptographically check to make sure that like okay I've got a public certificate and a
private key you can actually use open SSL uh it uh in order to uh look at look at the the
values from it and sure enough the the certificate matched the private key so it's a match.
This is legit I've got a private key to a certificate that was issued by Apple that I extracted
from my Fortinet firewall software. Pretty exciting. Alright so what if I was an attacker?
Right so you know uh in their final response that will the the that they came out with uh they
acknowledged that uh these certificates are actually used for both their Apple and Google Cloud
messaging services. So does this mean I could send push notifications to people's phones from as a
as Fortinet? Yeah you know it when I figured this out pretty early on that's why at the point
that I'm like this is bad I had I went ahead and reported it to Fortinet. I'd actually never
worked with Fortinet and didn't know of anybody that had so I gave them the benefit of the doubt.
Um and so uh what this is probably two weeks I it was literally two weeks after we had the
Netfigure thing go on is when I first reported this incident or this issue to uh to to Fortinet and
I also reached out to Apple. I mean I'm like hey Apple I've got the private key to a certificate
you guys issued. Uh I I felt that they should know uh also and actually it's it was interesting
Apple like responded back to me like we need to know whose key you've got access to. I mean
they were like tell us what you know tell me who your daddy is and what does he do right? Uh and
uh and I was a little uh luckily you know after I I told Fortinet that I'd reached out to Apple
as well. You know they self reported themselves to Apple and you know it was all all in a merry
way. Um and then um and then actually I was I issued a CVE uh in February of 2020-6645.
Anybody ever heard that one? No if you still look it's still actually not even uh allocated.
Um but they they told me in April, April 2020 that they're coming with a fix in 6.4.1 and
actually I think it ended up in 6.4.2 but they wanted me to wait. You know what's really
interesting is these this is more than just like I found a problem that you know firmware
update can kind of fix. This is like an architectural issue in their infrastructure right?
So no longer should you know should your firewall be able to talk directly to Apple and Google
and send a push notification. No. They're um and so this is actually an architectural issue.
So we you know we had discussions around they need to come up with a solution then they had
to push it out and then they wanted me to wait until um you know a sufficient enough time
had passed that enough customers had updated their firmware. I was like totally cool. I I'm
right on board with you. You know I'm a I was a Fortinet customer at the time. I'm like
totally on board with it. And then I waited. This was April 2020 when I kind of last talked
with them. Uh and then I waited and I waited and I waited. And three years later April of
2023 or sorry February of 2023 um they finally issued the the uh the advisory. It wasn't
without pro- I I was poking and prodding them probably every um every you know three or
four months something like that. Uh and they uh they never they they kept uh being like oh
yeah I actually went through uh three PSIRT representatives. Like I ended up you know
every time you know every few months a a new person was running the program. Uh and uh but
they finally acknowledged it in February 2023. I think they actually it took them at least
two two and a half years to fix it. Uh but to acknowledge it it was uh February 16th
2023. And you see it's got a different CVE number. So what they actually they were like
internal first internal reasons that are that I don't understand. They had to renumber the
CVE to 202222302 even though I reported it back in 2020. So that's an interesting story
that I'm sure I will never hear about. Um uh you know maybe it was too long between when it
was reported and when they reported the fix. I don't know. And they could only go back so
far. But wait that's not all. So uh fast forward I think it was actually January or February
of this year I was on I was helping one of my uh penetration testers on his external
penetration test. So we found a Fortinet firewall on the public internet that was acting
as a VPN server. Very common in a lot of people's organizations. Uh but we did a password
guessing attack. Uh and we found a username and password that worked. That let us uh kind
of get past that first door. But they had MFA turned on. Good for them. Uh and so we didn't
have a good way of bypassing their MFA. So I thought hey I we're we're FortiFriends. Uh we I
reached out and got the latest version of the software. The same same software that I used
to run. And I got the latest version. I was like uh because it was the software our our the
version our client was running. And I uh decided to look through the firmware to see if I
could find some kind of an MFA bypass right. You know what's great is since I I uh managed
the team I don't get my own engagements. So I get to jump into all my co-workers
engagements to kind of help them and I'll like sometimes swing from swing for the fences
and and sometimes it'll hit a home run. Sometimes I'll just do some interesting things. In
this particular case uh I got sidetracked because as I was looking through the firmware
looking at all the code I found the fix for the issue that I reported three years ago.
Which is actually the preface uh preface to why they finally published uh the their advisory
is because I poked them I'm like hey I see you've got the fix in the software. I don't know
exactly when it came out. But hopefully it's been long enough since it's been three years
uh to go ahead and uh and talk about it. And uh and that's when uh but but then the fix was
really super interesting. So I go uh most of the the the firmware on Fortinet is in a giant
init file right. So it's kind of like BusyBox uh where you've got like a massive binary and
then you link to it with LS you link to it with RM and CP and bending on the file name that
you're running it as it'll hit that executable differently and run on a little bit different
version of the program. Well that's how Fortinet's firmware is mostly set up. And inside of
that that that init file I found uh a URL product API dot Fortinet dot com. And uh it's right
there highlighted in black. Uh and and right above it it says iOS iOS push data. And then
above that you see uh you see uh FGT dot CRT and FGT dot key. Guess what those are? Any
ideas? Organizational private key in the in the green shirt. Oh back there. Oh still not
gonna be an NFL player sorry. Nice work. Uh yeah so this time uh this time I discovered
that uh they have another private key. Uh and so I went ahead uh I went ahead and uh and uh
tried to talk to this product API dot Fortinet dot com. Um and it it gave me you know a
handshake failure right? So I just tried to curl against it uh and it's like nope not gonna
be able to talk to me. So then I'm like well this is probably a client certificate to do
client uh authentication against the URL. So sure enough do the curl again. Pass it in
the Fortinet uh issued certificate and private key and uh yep I can talk to the URL. So I
didn't dig any deeper than this so uh I I'll I don't have anything more to report here but
let's just hope that the authentication between your firewall and their push notification
proxy server has more authentication than just a private key that's on their firmware. I
don't know. So that's where I left that. Alright so what did we learn from Fortinet now
that uh for this example? You know I'm convinced private keys are everywhere and uh I'm
only showing you three different examples today. I've got so many more uh in my library it's
it's ridiculous. And um and I've also found that manufacturers may not prioritize this type
of an issue right? Especially when they're hard problems right? This is an in particular
an architect architectural issue. They had to now stand up an entire site on the internet
that all of their customers are now going to hit. I mean this is a this is kind of a this is
kind of a big change for them and it can take some time a really long time in this case to
actually address it. So we need to be careful. But then we kept finding private keys. So in
my line of business you know we go kind of the extra mile to uh to to find all the weaknesses
in your organization and private keys are very useful on penetration tests right? So let's
fast forward a little bit more to April of this year. Uh my team was uh conducting an internal
penetration test. Uh you know basically what happens on our internal penetration test is
we'll we'll take a box uh a server box that we run our own uh distribution Linux distribution
on and we'll send it to the customer and we'll have them plug it into the network you know and
get us either on a user subnet or as if it's like plugged into a conference room. Basically
no level of access and this thing will find its way out of their network, connect back to our
infrastructure and allow us to pivot in to do our work to to find vulnerabilities. And so you
know one of the first things that we do you know as part of discovery on your network in an
internal penetration test is look for for for low hanging fruit look for for vulnerabilities
right? We'll use a vulnerability scanner and uh uh my coworker who is running this internal

like hey uh I found I got access to what was reported as a uh Palo Alto firewall uh with
that with default credentials but I got into it and it does not look like a Palo Alto
firewall. And guess what credentials he used to get into it with? Hey who said admin admin?
Hey who said admin admin? That guy here we go. Sorry that was the one I drank out of you
might want to watch that one. My bad that was the last one. Uh yeah admin admin so that's
how we got into this thing and we didn't he didn't know what it was I didn't know what it was
um it was kind of a mysterious device it it looked like it was running some version of like
maybe a CentOS uh looking through process lists uh looking through uh file systems you know
we we found we found that this is an interesting thing. So uh first of all we started looking

that's cool. So that means that that password has to be able to be read by the

um you know there I I enlarged it so you can see it a little bit. So there's a a jar file that

util or in this particular case you just use I just used unzip unzip the jar file and it it

Uh and I decided I'd just start going down the list. I started with the confutil.class I'm

cool technique how I can use a partial hard drive download to then convert it to QCOW2

known good boot so like I've like manually patched in packet so I can like go after the
